Topic.Title: LOL if AAPL goes green before AMZN

Message.Msg: party: I have 50% of my net worth in AAPL. I don't believe in diversification. I bought it last November at $375 because it was grossly undervalued and still is. Yah, I was late to the game, but earnings were growing faster than the stock price, making it a bargain at $375 (LOL). The parabolic run is a symptom of how undervalued it is, not tulip mania. At some point it will get overvalued and have trouble keeping up, but I figure that's at least 4 years away. One of the differences between Disney and Apple is that Apple is a global phenomena. Another difference is that HDTV is relatively new and global. Television as we know it is very vulnerable to change and I believe Steve Jobs had a vision about it just before he died. BTW, I was SHORT RIM in 2008 even though Blackberries were selling like hot cakes. Reason: It was a one product company and the product was mediocre. Also keep in mind that at a PE of 10, APPL will have 50% cash in 5 years if the stock price simply stays where its at and earnings don't grow. Except AAPLs earnings are growing at 50%/year.

Topic.Title: LOL if AAPL goes green before AMZN

Message.Msg: Edison: You will lose badly over the next year if you have half in AAPL. I am scaling into an Apple short. Did you realize GOOG/MMI has sued for an injunction against Siri devices? Apple has created a very high stakes game going after injunctions and it is a game of judo. Apple has far more to lose than anyone else and Google can withstand a dual ban much better than Apple. I'm not saying it is going to happen, but the majority of Apple's market cap depends upon a device than could be subject to import bans around the world because of Apple's ban centric IP strategy. It will be able to buy most players, but not GOOG, MMI, ORCL, MFST, etc. I am scaling into my short now. The only reason stocks are going parabolic is everyone is assuming infinite money printing and (effectively) hyperinflation via currency devaluation. They all are wrong (guilty of the affirmation bias). Put much more in cash. Seriously. The option value of cash is bigger than it has ever been...

Once again, why don't you short Dell, Best Buy or Hewlett Packard? I was thinking about that today. There are tons of great shorts out there, Which is a sign that a bear market is around the corner. But it's too soon to short AMZN and you are absolutely crazy to short AAPL. We are 3 weeks away from the biggest global consumer product launch in history. Even after the launch, I dont see sales slowing down until after Xmas.

Topic.Title: LOL if AAPL goes green before AMZN

Message.Msg: Edison: That simply isn't true. The primary misunderstanding of the patent system is that it conveys a negative right and not a positive right. Thus, anyone with a valid patent which Apple is infringing (and, with a device as complex as a smartphone, it is VERY hard not to infringe anything) can seek injunctive relief, although it won't necessarily be granted. I worked on the Patent Reform bills over the past 5 years, so I know a little about all the problems with IP (from USPTO latency to patent trolls...). Traditionally, the electronics industry cross licensed IP and allowed everyone to practive. Apple changed all that... Because it has itself gotten injunctive relief, its competitors are FAR more likely to get it in return. Tit for tat is most harmful to Apple because it has the most value at risk, but in aggregate and on a per SKU basis. In fact, if I were CEO of RIMM or SNE, I would be seeking injunctive relief from Apple heading into the holiday season (soon). Apple simply could not afford to have a ban for the holiday season. It would be compelled to buy the IP from said companies at a ridiculous premium at soon as they got an injunction. This is the high stakes game that Apple created and that MOMO followers are blind to. Apple depends upon 1 product for what 70% of its profits? That, my friend, is very risky. Edison, I short these because of people like you. Because most people have lost all perspective on true value and risk...

Topic.Title: LOL if AAPL goes green before AMZN

Message.Msg: Tech: please tell me more about yourself. Your posts are well written but make no sense. I am a 62 year old computer engineer contractor. Right now I specialize in automotive electronics. 10 years ago I specialized in telecommunications. When I was contracting at Motorola (Mobility) in Libertyville in 1993, The middle manager who signed my time card confided in me about a patent suit Mot was having. I believe the complaint was IDCC. The patent described how cell phones worked to a T. My boss said the patent was too broad. I couldn't see how Mot was going to win this one, but they did! Now throw in that most telecom patents are really vague attempts to patent software, Which is illegal, and I conclude that most telecom patents are invalid. Patents only give you the right to go to court, making it a rich mans game, And driving your competitors out of the market place. Google is now fighting back because their Android franchise is in jepordy. If they win, Apple can fight back and the result will be a ban on all apple and android phones. It's unimaginable.

Topic.Title: LOL if AAPL goes green before AMZN

Message.Msg: I'm not saying it's a bubble , but that doesn't mean AAPL is as cheap as people think with it's huge earnings base here standing @ last 4 qtr 42.54, which it's not growing 50 % from anymore. That being said, earnings growth won't fall off a cliff , but will slow, and then earnings will fall ahead: that's just a fact of nature . AAPL has the best execution ever and the market cap being the highest ever in the US stock market and more than 50 % more than the next does reflect some of it. It's stuffed to the gills with funds owning it as it should right now and tons fo hedge funds chasing it up. It will look cheap for not much longer. Certainly has more buffers than others with it's huge cash takein right now and instillation of the dividend.

Topic.Title: QE may be counter productive

Message.Msg: of course it is for the non-investor focused class: it will send costs that the Fed accounts for little like food and energy through the roof: especially open ended QE. And it will also solidy a huge asset paper bubble in financial assets on the Fed's balance further balance sheet expansion. They are acting more like a hedge fund than a reasonable Central Bank: to them, "price stability" includes overlooking the formation of bubbles and malinvestment.

Message.Title: Something for longs to think hard about
Message.Msg: Best Buy sales have plunged. Some of you think that is because AMZN is stealing their business. That is not true. Look at results and guidance from Dell and HPQ. Nobody is buying from anybody. Americans are broke, and they are scared. If you think it is bad here, look overseas where AMZN has a lot of their operations. It is much worse there than it is here. I know, most of you think it is not important for AMZN to have good sales, and make money. You are living in a dream world, and you will have a rude awakening. The fiscal cliff is coming, and along with it, we are facing much higher taxes on capital gains and investment income. That is going to flush out lot of longer term holders before the end of the year who know they had better lock in their long term gains before they get raped by higher taxes next year. Once the wave of selling starts, there will be no stopping it. It will simply feed on itself, just like Facebook.

Topic.Title: Shorts, are you sad?

Message.Msg: You sum it up pretty good. But in the bigger cycle, AMZN will drop sharply in a very short period of time. It will happen after November when the election is over. It might even come sooner if it is clear Obama is not going to win. But so far, the best action is to wait on the sideline and wait until Obama wins in November. Then stocks should plunge 30% or more in December going to the first quarter of 2013.

Message.Title: Playing AMZN short
Message.Msg: A safer way to play AMZN short is via options. This morning you could buy the Oct $230 puts under $6. Later today you could sell for nearly $7. Even when AMZN moves higher you still don't lose much because of the time premium. I also like the idea that these puts cover most of Sept and Oct. Chances are you can pick these puts up under $6 sometime today or tomorrow. Buy a partial position and add on any big spikes, taking profit on the swings. Don't buy unless you get it around $6 or lower IMO.

Topic.Title: Playing AMZN short

Message.Msg: buying puts in AMZN is historically a losers game. You have to be a great timer to get out before erosion guts you. And that's not including the times AMZN runs up. Not an options guy but the put seller over time have been the huge winners selling to the retail who think it's overvalued and , at the least, hold it up or move it higher. Every onece in awhile I guess they can work, but the upside squeezes tell me that the call buyers make out the best. Don't know about right now either way. That's the history. Options for AMZN are usually played on the bull side against the valuation logic.

Message.Title: Rating the Price Move after the Conference
Message.Msg: Spectacular: Amazon treads water or falls 10% (sell the news reaction) Middling Good: Amazon falls 10-20% HoHum (phone in oversaturated market?): Amazon falls 20-40% Bad news (?): Amazon falls 40-60% Can the bulls suggest what a "spectacular" announcement would be? A phone? I would rate that as "ho hum". Amazon delivering to locker stores as was reported yesterday? That would establish a physical presence, and subject them to taxation, wouldn't it? Maybe I'm wrong, but I don't see how at this valuation level.

Topic.Title: AMZN will fall like PCLN and CMG

Message.Msg: criminal bezos days are numbered: the day this crook launch smart phone, SCAMZON will crash and burn Contract Manufacturer. Amazon may go straight to a contract manufacturer, like Foxconn, rather than try to private label a phone from Motorola, Samsung or HTC. Amazon designs the Kindle and has it integrated by an Asian contract manufacturer. Amazon has come a long way in the last five years in making devices with the Amazon’s name stamped on. Strategy. Amazon may want the phone as gateway to its website to encourage shopping. Amazon could adopt the razor and blade strategy—sell the razors below cost and make money on the blades. The web giant has a loss-leader strategy for the Kindle, where is loses money on the hardware, but profits on e-books. Amazon can leverage its other businesses, and get into the smartphone business at a low incremental cost. Amazon could minimize outlays by building the phone itself, use its extensive telecom infrastructure (it spent $8 billion network facilities in 2011) to cut out the carrier and expand its rights for books and movies to any electronic device.
